item.title: Bandwidth To Support Branch Offices
item.description: Many businesses need multiple locations in a region to stay close to their customers. Connecting these branches seamlessly without breaking the bank is a common challenge. Thankfully, two high-performance networking technologies, Metro Ethernet and MPLS Networks, offer affordable solutions that weren’t available even a decade ago. Carrier Ethernet takes the local networking capabilities of Ethernet and extends them across entire cities. This means easy connection and efficient transmission without needing protocol conversions.

item.title: Qwest Embraces Ethernet over Copper to Reach Rural Business Locations
item.description: Qwest Communications, a leading telecom provider in the US, boasts a nationwide fiber optic network capable of transmitting data at 40 Gbps, with plans to upgrade to 100 Gbps. While this caters to large enterprises requiring substantial bandwidth, what options are available for remotely located businesses? Remote offices, even those belonging to large corporations, often face challenges justifying the cost of installing fiber optic cables due to their distance from carrier Points of Presence (POPs).

item.title: Cloud Communications Advantages Explained
item.description: Many businesses are unsure if switching their communications to the cloud is a good idea. XO Communications, a large networking and telecom provider, explains why this change is beneficial. Their short video illustrates why this might be the right choice for your business. XO’s Enterprise Cloud Communications provides large businesses with services similar to what hosted PBX systems offer smaller companies. Essentially, it transitions a company from managing its own phone system to simply using a sophisticated service.

item.title: XO Launches SIP for Multi-Location Businesses
item.description: XO Communications, a large telecommunications company, has introduced a new solution that allows businesses with numerous locations to take advantage of enterprise VoIP technology. Connecting business locations to a phone service provider through SIP trunking is a well-established method for improving network performance and saving money. XO is building on this concept with a multi-site SIP trunking solution. Instead of requiring each location to connect to a remote service provider separately, branch offices, warehouses, and other locations can now use their existing Wide Area Network (WAN) to connect SIP phones back to a central IP-PBX system at the main office.

item.title: POTS Phone Service For Multiple Locations
item.description: Businesses with numerous branches across the US, Canada, and Puerto Rico often struggle with a mountain of paperwork. This isn’t due to government forms but rather a deluge of phone bills from managing services at multiple locations. Initially, a company starts at one location, orders phone and internet services, and handles one or two bills. Someone reviews these bills for errors, unused services, or potential misuse. However, as the company expands to new locations, each branch typically sets up its own phone service, leading to separate bills and individual reviews, multiplying the administrative burden significantly.
